prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Field & Spatial Resolution: -------------------------- We want to map the CO(1-0) emission in the galaxy with an uniform surface density rms (10 Msun/pc2) to cover the main disk with a single pointing. To detect the finest details of the CO(1-0) emission in the gas disk and to get the requested surface density rms we set a spatial resolution of 0.5" optimizing the spatial resolution and the sensitivity. Given the distance of the galaxy and the expected size of the whole gas disk (<5 kpc) we do not need of the ACA to retrieve the largest scale emission completely covered by the 12-m array.
Spectral Setup: --------------- We need to get a velocity resolution of 20 km/s to get at least 15 channels covered with the emission and be able to study the kinematics. We setup 1 baseband of 1.8 GHz bandwidth/1MHz and the rest with TDM setup to map the continuum of the radio galaxy.
Sensitivity: ----------- We expect to have at least a peak intensity of ~ 50 mJy/beam for the CO(1-0) in the targets according to our IRAM-30m detection (See scientific case). Such an high SNR is needed to reach the low surface density threshold we aim for. This is needed to reach the most extended molecular gas in the outer part of the gas disk.

Field & Spatial Resolution: -------------------------- We want to map the CO(1-0) emission in the galaxy with an uniform surface density rms (10 Msun/pc2) to cover the main disk with a single pointing. To detect the finest details of the CO(1-0) emission in the gas disk and to get the requested surface density rms we set a spatial resolution of 0.5" optimizing the spatial resolution and the sensitivity. Given the distance of the galaxy and the expected size of the whole gas disk (<5 kpc) we do not need of the ACA to retrieve the largest scale emission completely covered by the 12-m array.
Spectral Setup: -------------- We need to get a velocity resolution of 20 km/s to get at least 15 channels covered with the emission and be able to study the kinematics. We setup 4 BBs of 1.8 GHz bandwidth/1MHz to detect CO(1-0) and possible absorption lines in the other BBs. This explains why we reach a higher data rate than the standard one.
Sensitivity: ----------- We expect to have a peak intensity of at least 10-20 mJy/beam for the CO(1-0) in the targets according to our IRAM-30m detection (See scientific case). Such SNR is needed to reach the low surface density threshold we aim for. This is needed to reach the most extended molecular gas in the outer part of the gas disk. The continuum emission will be detected with a very high SNR (>1000)

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Radio galaxies are hosted predominantly by massive elliptical galaxies. They represent an intense phase in the evolution of massive galaxies that is associated with star formation, Black Hole (BH) growth, and extreme feedback. Their Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) produce jets with powerful synchrotron radio power, and depending on their morphology they have been classify as FR-I or FR-II. The difference in the host galaxy between these two classification is still a challenge in modern astrophyscis. We propose to use high-resolution, high-sensitivity data with ALMA to learn about physical distinction between FR-I and FR-II galaxies by studying the distribution of the molecular gas and its interaction with the AGN.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Centre for astrophysics , Porto, University of
